lines.content: This is a project is a basic chatbot which can be used to keep track of your tasks at hand.
Head to [releases](https://github.com/flyingsalsa/ip/releases/tag/v0.1.1) on how to use it!

### Note that all commands are NOT case-sensitive and the very FIRST word before a whitespace will be read as the command.
Most commands must be of the form (command) xxx where xxx is follow up text. For example,
### where "todo" is the (command) and "new task" is the follow up text xxx.
1. **list** - gives a list of all current tasks, all text after list will not be read
1. **mark** - marks task given in the follow up text as completed by filling in the empty [  ] with a cross [X].  Follow up text must be a valid integer.
1. **unmark** - unmarks a task given in the follow up text as completed reverting the [X] to a [  ].  Follow up text must be a valid integer.
1. **delete** - deletes task given in the follow up text.  Follow up text must be a valid integer.
2. **find** - searches through all tasks and returns a list of tasks that contain the followup text.

* This class is responsible for handling the reading and parsing of tasks from the data.txt file.
* Reads tasks from a specified file and returns them as an ArrayList.
* Each line in the file is parsed into a {@link Task} object.
* If a task is successfully parsed and is considered "real" (as determined by {@link Task#isReal()}),
* it is added to the returned list. Tasks that cannot be parsed or are not "real" are skipped.
* @param filePath the path to the file containing the tasks
* @return an {@link ArrayList} of {@link Task} objects read from the file
* @throws IOException if an error occurs while reading the file
private static void setCompletionStatus(Task task, String status) {
* This class is responsible for handling the reading and parsing of Dates inside {@link String} objects and converting
* them to {@link LocalDate} and then reformatting them back to a new {@link String} with corrected formatting.
* Reads the input String and returns it in the desired format
* @return reformatted {@link String} after being parsed as a {@link LocalDate} and back into the desired format
* Represents a task that has a deadline by which it must be completed.
* A deadline task includes a description and a specific "by" time, which
* indicates when the task needs to be completed.
* Constructs a {@code Deadline} object from a string input.
* The input string is expected to contain a task description followed by
* a "/by" keyword and the deadline time.
* @param s the string containing the task description and deadline time
* @throws IllegalArgumentException if the input string is missing either the task description
*                                  or the "by" time, or if either part is empty.
throw new IllegalArgumentException("Deadlines must include both a task description "
+ "and a 'by' time and not include extra \"/\"...");
* Returns a string representation of the deadline task, including its type, description,
* and the deadline by which it must be completed.
* @return a string in the format "[D] description (by: deadline)"
* Represents an event task that occurs within a specific time frame.
* An event has a description, a start time, and an end time. The start and end times
* are specified using the "/from" and "/to" keywords, respectively, within the input string.
* Constructs an {@code Event} object from a string input.
* The input string is expected to contain a task description followed by
* a "from" time and a "to" time, separated by the "/" character.
* @param s the string containing the task description and time information
* @throws IllegalArgumentException if the input string is invalid, missing the task description,
throw new IllegalArgumentException("Events must include both task description and 'from' "
* The {@code Storage} class manages the storage, retrieval, and manipulation of tasks.
* Tasks are stored in a text file, and this class provides methods for creating,
* modifying, and deleting tasks. The tasks are loaded from a file on initialization
* and saved back to the file whenever they are modified.
* Constructs a {@code Storage} object and initializes it by loading tasks from the specified file.
* If the file exists, tasks are read from it. If not, a new file is created. The tasks are stored in an
* {@link ArrayList} and can be manipulated through various methods provided by this class.
System.out.println("Data found and loaded from: " + filePath.toAbsolutePath());
System.out.println("*the first word will always be read as the command*");
System.out.println("New Data file successfully created at: " + filePath.toAbsolutePath());
System.out.println("*the first word will always be read as the command*");
* Writes the current list of tasks to the storage file.
* This method clears the file's contents before writing the updated list of tasks.
* Adds a new {@code Todo} task to the list and writes the updated list to the file.
* @param s the description of the todo task
* Adds a new {@code Event} task to the list and writes the updated list to the file.
* @param s the description of the event task
* Adds a new {@code Deadline} task to the list and writes the updated list to the file.
* @param s the description of the deadline task
* Returns a string representation of all the tasks in the list.
* Each task is represented by its index in the list, followed by its string representation.
* @return a string representation of all tasks
* Marks the task at the specified index as completed and writes the updated list to the file.
* @param i the index of the task to mark as completed
* Unmarks the task at the specified index as not completed and writes the updated list to the file.
* @param i the index of the task to unmark as not completed
* Deletes the task at the specified index from the list and writes the updated list to the file.
* @param i the index of the task to delete
* Finds tasks in the list that contain the specified keyword in their description.
* Returns a string of all matching tasks, each prefixed by its index in the list.
* @param s the keyword to search for in the task descriptions
* @return a string of matching tasks, each on a new line
* Clears out the entire Storage Arraylist and cleans up any remaining data from the data.txt file as well
* Returns the number of tasks currently stored.
* @return the size of the task list
* The {@code Task} class represents a basic task with a description and a completion status.
* Tasks can be marked as completed or not completed, and their status is reflected in their string representation.
* Constructs a {@code Task} object with the specified task description.
* The task is initially marked as not completed.
* @param s the description of the task
* Marks the task as not completed.
* Returns a string representation of the task, including its completion status.
* The string format is "[X] task description" if the task is completed, or "[ ] task description" if not.
* Returns the description of the task.
* Checks if the task has a valid, non-empty description.
* @return {@code true} if the task description is not empty, {@code false} otherwise
* Represents a simple task with no specific time constraints.
* A {@code Todo} task extends {@code Task} and is identified by its type "[T]" in its string representation.
* Constructs a {@code Todo} object with the specified task description.
* This constructor initializes the task with the given description and
* @param s the description of the todo task
* Returns a string representation of the todo task, including its type.
* The string format is "[T][status] task description", where "[status]" is "[X]" if completed,
* @return a string representing the todo task
* The {@code Notgpt} class is a simple command-line application that serves as an interface
* for interacting with the user. It prints a logo and a greeting message, then passes control
* to a parser that processes user input.
* Prints a line divider to the console.
* This method is used to create a visual line separation between different sections
* The main method serves as the entry point for the application.
* It initializes the application by printing a logo and a greeting message,
* then passes control to the {@code Parser} to process user commands. Any exceptions
* that occur during execution are caught, logged to a file, and displayed to the user.
* @param args command-line arguments (not used in this application)
System.out.println(logo + "\n" + "hi, I'm Not-gpt,\ndo you really need me to do sth for you?");
System.out.println("An error occurred. Press Enter to exit.");
* The main driver class of the chatbot, called by notGPT
* Runs the entire program, reading user input and deciding what to do
* @param scanner system input from command line
System.out.println("it's empty... what do u want me to list? :(");
